bibl.title: Letter from Thomas C. Lazear to Mabel H. Lazear, May 14, 1908

div1.p: Thomas Lazear writes about the difficulties in passing a pension bill on behalf of the families of Carroll and Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Thomas C. Lazear to Mabel H. Lazear, May 14, 1908
div1.opener:
LAZEAR AND ORR
ATTORNEYS AT LAW
450 FOURTH AVENUE
PITTSBURGH, PA.
THOS. C. LAZEAR CHAS P. ORR
JESSE T. LAZEAR
Pittsburgh PaMay 14th 1908 Mrs. Mabel H. Lazear
Padre St
Santa Barbara. Cal
My dear Mabel-
div1.p:
I know you would be so glad to hear the
good news that on receipt of Mr Dalzells dispatch to me
I felt like sending you the contents of his message by
wire rather than sending it by mail. I have no doubt
my message was delivered to you yesterday- Mr. Dalzells'
was simply in these words. “The Lazear Carroll bill passed
the House today”,- I inferred from this that it was the
bill giving you a pension which had passed the Senate
weeks ago but the enclosed clipping from this mornings
2
LAZEAR AND ORR
ATTORNEYS AT LAW
450 FOURTH AVENUE
PITTSBURGH, PA.
THOS. C. LAZEAR CHAS P. ORR
JESSE T. LAZEAR
Pittsburgh Gazette shows that it was not and that the bill
passed yesterday was an entirely new bill though differing
from the forms only in the substitution of the word
“annuity” for the word “pension”- I can readily conjecture
why this change was made- The Pension Committee of
The House had a rule that no application for an
increase of pension would be entertained in any case where
the pension had been granted by a special act of Congress
That was exactly your case and the chairman of that
Committee insisted on a strict adherence to the rule
without exception- Mr Dalzell wrote me months ago that
3
LAZEAR AND ORR
ATTORNEYS AT LAW
450 FOURTH AVENUE
PITTSBURGH, PA.
THOS. C. LAZEAR CHAS P. ORR
JESSE T. LAZEAR
this rule was the great obstacle to overcome and I almost, for
that reason, looked upon our efforts in your behalf as loves
labor lost- Several days ago I wrote to Dr Mansfelde that
I was apprehensive of failures merely because of the existence
of this rule and I then suggested to him that my only hope was to
change the name of the relief we asked for from the name
of a pension to that of an annuity. Strange to say, this
was the very course presented to get over the difficulty-
How it happened I do not know but the coincidence
was remarkable- It has the desired effect however and
we ought to be satisfied. “A rose will smell as sweet
by any other name”. All we wanted was the rose.

LAZEAR AND ORR
ATTORNEYS AT LAW
450 FOURTH AVENUE
PITTSBURGH, PA.
THOS. C. LAZEAR CHAS P. ORR
JESSE T. LAZEAR

In addition to the telegram I sent to you I also sent one yesterday
afternoon to Dr Mansfelde- His untiring zeal for you and Mrs Carroll
in this matter has made me love the man- I have kept
up a constant correspondence with him for many months
in regard to yourself- He is coming to visit me next months
in compliance with my urgent invitation- I desired in
this way to express my gratitude for what he has done
for you- I never knew an instance of disinterested kindness
such as he has exhibited in the case of yourself and Mrs
Carroll- To Dr Mansfelde and to my friends Hon John
Dalzell and Senator Knox I feel that the most sucred and
lasting obligation of gratitude are one both from you and me-
5
LAZEAR AND ORR
ATTORNEYS AT LAW
450 FOURTH AVENUE
PITTSBURGH, PA.
THOS. C. LAZEAR CHAS P. ORR
JESSE T. LAZEAR
This new bill introduced yesterday by Mr Dalzell will have to go to
the Senate for concurrence by that body- But Senator Knox
will put it through and perhaps that may be done in
a day or two- And as the President personally recommended
this legislative, he will really sign the bill.

I suppose your mother is with you- If so, please
remember me to her and hug the dear children for me-
